turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Time?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Between six and seven seconds.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: The key is the second and third shots came right on top of each other, and it takes a minimum 2.3 seconds to recycle this thing.  The other problem is there was a tree right there...  Blocking the first two shots at the time they occur in the Zapruder film.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Didn't Hoover say something about that?  The leaves had fallen off in November?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: It was a Texas Live Oak, boss.  It sheds it's leaves the first week of March.  You try to hit a moving target at 88 yards through heavy foliage with this cheap 13-dollar sucker, the world's worst shoulder weapon.  No way.  The FBI tried two sets of tests and not one of their sharpshooters could match Oswald's performance.  Not one.  And Oswald was at best a medium shot.  The scope was defective on it, too.  I mean this is the whole essence of the case to me.  The guy couldn't do the shooting.  Nobody could.  And they sold this lemon to the American public.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: The Zapruder film is the proof they didn't count on, Lou.  We gotta get our hands on it.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: That means we gotta subpoena Time- Life on it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why not just shoot Kennedy coming up Houston?  There's plenty of time - he's out in the open - a frontal shot?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: When Kennedy gets to the kill zone, it's a turkey shoot.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: How many men?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: One shooter.  One spotter on a radio. Maybe three teams.  I'd say these were professional riflemen, chief, serious people.  Hunters...  patient. It takes skill to kill with a rifle, that's why there's been no execution of an executive with one in 200 years... "3-2-1...  green!"  Or else "Abort!  Abort!"

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Who do you think changed the parade route?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Beats me.  City officials.  Secret Service.  Dallas police.  They did a dry run with Chief Curry a few days before.  But they didn't bother running through Dealey.  They stopped right there, said something like, "and afterwards there's only the freeway," and went home.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You know who the mayor was?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Earle Cabell.  And guess who his brother is?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: General Charles Cabell.  Deputy Director of the CIA.  Fired by Kennedy in '61 because of the Bay of Pigs fiasco, he moved back to the Pentagon, called Kennedy a "traitor".  When he came to New Orleans to address the Foreign Policy Association, you know who introduced him?  Our friend Clay Shaw.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: The Warren Commission call him?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: His boss was the one on the Warren Commission who handled all the leads to the intelligence community.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Allen Dulles?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Head of the CIA since '53.  Kennedy fired them both.  Cabell was his deputy for nine years.  Talk about the fox investigating the chicken coop.  Now we'll have to subpoena them, Lou.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: They're gonna love you, chief.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Maybe we should just call it a day, Lou.  Go home.  While we're still a little behind.  We got two people killed, maybe more we never thought about.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: You never got anyone killed, boss. Their actions killed them years before.  If we stopped now, it'd be even more wrong.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Chief, I've had my doubts about Bill for a long time.  He's fighting everything.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We need him back.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: I just plain don't trust him anymore.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Maybe you didn't hear what I said. I will not tolerate this infighting among the staff, I warn you that...

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Boss, then I'm afraid I can't continue working with Bill.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Are you giving me an ultimatum, Lou?

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: Well, if that's what you want to call it.  I didn't ever think it would come to this.  I guess I am, boss.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I will not have any damned ultimatums put to me, Lou.  I'll accept your resignation.

turns.speaker: LOU
turns.text: You sure got it.  You're one stubborn and stupid sonofabitch D.A. and you're making one hell of a mistake!

turns.speaker: LONG
turns.text: Sad thing is the way it's screwing up this country, all these hippies running around on drugs, the way young people look you can't tell a boy from a girl anymore.  I saw a girl the other day, she was pregnant - you could see her whole belly, and you know what she painted on it? "Love Child."  It's fuckin' outa control.  Values've gone to hell, Jim... Course it figures when you got somebody like that polecat Johnson in the White House.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I sometimes feel things've gone downhill since John Kennedy was killed, Senator.

turns.speaker: LONG
turns.text: Don't get me started on that.  Those Warren Commission fellows were pickin' gnat shit out of pepper.  No one's gonna tell me that kid did the shooting job he did from that damned bookstore.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I thought the FBI test-fired the rifle to make sure it could be done?

turns.speaker: LONG
turns.text: Sure, three experts and not one of them could do it!  They're telling us Oswald got off three shots with world-class precision from a manual bolt action rifle in less than six seconds - and accordin' to his Marine buddies he got Maggie's drawers - he wasn't any good.  Average man would be lucky to get two shots off, and I tell ya the first shot would always be the best.  Here, the third shot's perfect.  Don't make sense.  And then they got that crazy bullet zigzagging all over the place so it hits Kennedy and Connally seven times. One "pristine" bullet?  That dog don't hunt.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You know, something always bothered me about that from day one, and I can't put my finger on it.

turns.speaker: LONG
turns.text: If I were investigatin', I'd round up the 100 best riflemen in the world and find out which ones were in Dallas that day.  You been duck hunting?  I think Oswald was a good old-fashioned decoy.  What'd he say?  "I'm just a patsy."  Out of the mouth of babes y'ask me.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You think there were other men involved, Russell?

turns.speaker: LONG
turns.text: Hell, you're the District Attorney. You read the Warren Report - and then you tell me you're satisfied Lee Oswald shot the President all by his lonesome.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Russell, honestly you sound like one of those kooky critics spreading paranoia like prairie fire.  I just can't believe the Chief Justice of the United States would put his name on something that wasn't true.

turns.speaker: LONG
turns.text: Honey, another one of these.  This one's as weak as cricket pee-pee. Yessir, you mark my words, Jim, Vietnam's gonna cost Johnson '68 and it's gonna put that other varmint Nixon in - then watch your hide, 'cause there ain't no offramps on a freeway to Hell!

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: Welcome, District Attorney Garrison. May I call you Jim?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I've been called everything under the sun, Jerry.  Call me whatever you like.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: There have been a number of reports in reputable news media - Time, Newsweek, our own NBC - that you have gone way beyond the legal means available to a prosecutor, that you've intimidated and drugged witnesses, bribed them, urged them to commit perjury.  What is your response?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Your faith in the veracity of the major media is touching, Jerry.  It indicates that the Age of Innocence is not yet over.  But seriously, Jerry, people aren't interested in Jim Garrison - they want the hard evidence!  They want to know why he was killed and what forces were opposed to...

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: Some people would say you're paranoid.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, if I am, why is the Government concealing evidence?

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: Are they?  Why would they?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's exactly my question, Jerry. Maybe I'd better show you some pictures so you can begin to understand what I am talking about.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: Pictures like this don't show up on television!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Sure they do.  The camera can pick this up.

turns.speaker: JOHNSON
turns.text: No, it can't!

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: Jim Garrison?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: I'm glad you came.  I'm sorry about the precautions.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, I just hope it was worth my while, Mr...

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: I could give you a false name, but I won't.  Just call me X.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I've already been warned by the Agency, Mr. Whoever.  If this is another type of threat, I don't...

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: I'm not with the Agency, Mr. Garrison, and I assume if you've come this far, what I have to say interests you.  But I'm not going to name names, or tell you who or what I represent. Except to say - you're close, you're closer than you think...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't... I can't believe it.  They killed him because he wanted to change things.  In our time - in our country?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: Kings are killed, Mr. Garrison. Politics is power, nothing more. But don't believe me.  Don't trust me.  Do your own work, your own thinking.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: The size of this is... beyond me. Testify?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: No chance in hell, Mr. Garrison. I'd be arrested and gagged, declared insane and hospitalized... maybe worse.  You, too.  I can only give you background, you got to find the foreground, the little things... Keep digging.  Y'know you're the only person to ever bring a trial in the murder of John Kennedy.  That's important - it's historic.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I haven't yet.  I don't have much of a case.

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: But you don't have a choice anymore. You've become a significant threat to the national security structure. They would've killed you already, but you got a lot of light on you. Instead, they're gonna destroy your credibility; they already have in many circles in this town.  You're some kinda ego-crazed southern caricature to many folks.  Be honest - the best chance you got is come up with a case, something, anything, make arrests, stir the shitstorm. You gotta hope to reach a point of critical mass where other people will come forward and the government will crack.  Remember, fundamentally people are suckers for the truth, and the truth is on your side, 'bubba. I hope you get a break...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, thanks for coming.

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: You didn't get that break you needed, but you went as far as any man could, bubba.  What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Just speculating, I guess.  How do you think it started?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: I think it started in the wind. Money - arms, big oil, Pentagon people, contractors, bankers, politicians like L.B.J. were committed to a war in Southeast Asia.  As early as '61 they knew Kennedy was going to change things... He was not going to war in Southeast Asia.  Who knows? Probably some boardroom or lunchroom somewhere - Houston, New York - hell, maybe Bonn, Germany... who knows, it's international now.

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: He's done it before.  Other countries. Lumumba in the Congo, Trujillo, the Dominican Republic, he's working on Castro.  No big deal.  In September, Kennedy announces the Texas trip. At that moment, second Oswalds start popping up all over Dallas where they have the mayor and the cops in their pocket.  Y flies in the assassins, maybe from the special camp we keep outside Athens, Greece - pros, maybe some locals, Cubans, Maria hire, separate teams.  Does it really matter who shot from what rooftop?  Part of the scenery.  The assassins by now are dead or well paid and long gone...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Any chance of one of them confessing someday?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: ...don't think so.  When they start to drool, they get rid of 'em.  These guys are proud of what they did. They did Dealey Plaza!  They took out the President of the United States!  That's entertainment!  And they served their country doing it.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: ...and your General?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: ...got promoted to two stars, but he was never military, you know, always CIA.  Went to Vietnam, lost his credibility when we got beat over there, retired, lives in Virginia. I say hello to him when I see him at the supermarket...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Ever ask him?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: You never ask a spook a question. No point.  He'll never give you a straight answer.  General Y still thinks of himself of the handsome young warrior who loved this country but loved the concept of war more.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: His name?

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: Does it matter?  Another technician. But an interesting thing - he was there that day in Dealey Plaza.  You know how I know?  That picture of yours.  The hoboes... you never looked deep enough...

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: I knew the man 20 years.  That's him.  The way he walked... arms at his side, military, the stoop, the haircut, the twisted left hand, the large class ring.  What was he doing there?  If anyone had asked him, he'd probably say "protection" but I'll tell you I think he was giving some kind of "okay" signal to those hoboes - they're about to get booked and he's telling 'em it's gonna be okay, they're covered.  And in fact they were - you never heard of them again.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: ...some story... the whole thing. It's like it never happened.

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: It never did.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Just think... just think.  What happened to our country .. to the world...  because of that murder... Vietnam, racial conflict, breakdown of law, drugs, thought control, guilt, assassinations, secret government fear of the frontier...

turns.speaker: X
turns.text: I keep thinking of that day, Tuesday the 26th, the day after they buried Kennedy, L.B.J. was signing the memorandum on Vietnam with Ambassador Lodge.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Here's my problem, Jack.  You told me you and Guy were good friends for a long time?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: More than ten years.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And he never hit you before?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Never touched me.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yet on November 22, 1963 - the day of the President's murder - our police report says he pistol-whipped you with a .357 Magnum.  But the police report says you had an argument over the phone bill. Here, take a look at it.  Now, does a simple argument over phone bills sound like a believable explanation to you?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: How much more?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I don't know if I should talk about this.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Well, I'd ask Guy - we were friendly, you know - heart attack, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: If you buy what you read in the paper.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You have other information?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: I didn't say that.  All I know is he died suddenly just before the Warren Report came out.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Why did Guy beat you, Jack?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Well, I guess now that Guy's dead, it don't really matter... it was about the people hanging around the office that summer.  I wasn't really part of the operation, you know.  I was handling the private-eye work for Guy when that came in - not much did - but that's why I was there... it was a nuthouse.  There were all these Cubans coming and going.  They all looked alike to me.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Dave Ferrie - you know about him?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Was he there often?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Often?  He practically lived there. It was real cloak and dagger stuff. They called it Operation Mongoose. The idea was to train all these Cuban exiles for another invasion of Cuba. Banister's office was part of a supply line that ran from Dallas, through New Orleans to Miami, stockpiling arms and explosives.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Where is Banister in all this?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Banister was running his camp north of Lake Pontchartrain.  Ferrie handled a lot of the training.  There was a shooting range and a lot of tropical terrain like in Cuba.  A few Americans got trained, too.  Nazi types. Mercenaries.  But Ferrie was the craziest.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Like I said, a fuckin' nuthouse.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And Oswald?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah, he was there, too... sometimes he'd be meeting with Banister with the door shut.  Other times he'd be shooting the bull with Ferrie.  But he was there all right.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Anything more specific, Jack?  It's important.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Anyone else involved at Banister's level?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: There was one guy, I don't know, big guy, business guy, white hair - I saw him come into the office once. He looked out of place, y'know - like a society guy.  Can't remember his name.  Oswald was with him.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Clay something, that was his name - Clay.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Bertrand.  Clay Bertrand?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Yeah!  That's it.  I don't know.  Maybe it wasn't.  I gotta go.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Clay Bertrand.  He's in the Warren Report.  He tried to get Oswald a lawyer.  Was Kennedy ever discussed, Jack?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Sure.  'Course they hated the sonofabitch, but...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: The assassination, Jack?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: Never.  Not with me sir, never... Listen, I think I'd better go.  I said enough.  I said all I'm going to say.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Hold on, Jack.  What's the problem?

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: What's the problem?  What's the problem?  Do I need to spell it out for you, Mr. Garrison?  I better go.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Nobody knows what we're talking about, Jack.

turns.speaker: MARTIN
turns.text: You're so naive, mister.

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: Didn't someone say he didn't speak good Russian?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It's a contradiction, Numa, get used to them.  The only explanation for the royal treatment is he did give them radar secrets.  Or fake secrets.

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: Even my own wife, chief,  Who's wondering where I am?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Even your own wife, Numa.  Any of you want to quit, do me a favor... put us out of our misery.

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: HOLD IT, CHIEF...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: You just need some sleep, Lou.  It won't look so bad when...

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: Well, believe what you want, boss, but we got to be more careful.  All these new volunteers, any one of them could be...

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Okay, you handle it, Numa.  I don't have time for this nonsense.  We've obviously got the bastards worried now.  I'm going to Washington.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: No, she could get hurt.  If you believe what's happening to these other people.

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: She's the best damn witness we have!

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I just don't want to do it.  What else?

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: Hate mail here.  Fan mail here.  The bad news is the IRS has just requested an audit on your income from this office.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I expected that two months ago, and they're wasting their time... The bad news is the National Guard has just asked me to resign after 18 years.  Well, maybe that's good news - it was never as good as combat, but this is.  Bill, any more on Oswald and Shaw?

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: Sure sounds like he's winning.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: He'll never make it.  If he wins, they'll kill him.  He wants to avenge his brother.  He'll stop that war. No, they'll kill him before they let him become President.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I don't think so, Al.  You remember the Hemingway story, "The Old Man and the Sea"?  The old fisherman manages to catch this great fish - a fish so huge he has to tie it to the side of the boat to get it back in.  But by the time he reached shore, the fish had long since been picked apart by sharks and nothing was left but the skeleton.

turns.speaker: NUMA
turns.text: Then what are we going through all this trouble for?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: It's a means to an end.  This war has two fronts - in the court of law, we hope, against the odds, to nail Clay Shaw on a conspiracy charge. In the court of public opinion, it could take another 25 or 30 years for the truth to come out, but at least we're going to strike the first blow.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Welcome, Mr. Miller.  Jim Garrison. Would you care for some coffee?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Yes, thank you, Mr. Garrison.  Your coffee's almost Turkish down here but I could get used to it.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I'm glad you could find time to see me.  I flew down from Denver this morning on my private jet.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Yes, your letter indicated you were in he oil business up there.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I've done quite well in Denver, Mr. Garrison, but I have to admire someone like you - and I have the means to back up what I say.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: We can use all the support we can get.  I think these might interest you.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: They've been enlarged and show a lot of detail...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Splendid, love to see them.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Where were you?  Europe, Pacific?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Germany.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: You were lucky.  I spent three years in the Pacific.  I've never seen an avenue with such a profusion of bail-bonding companies. Why is that?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: I imagine because this is the Criminal District Court Building  This is an enlargement of a potential shooter standing behind the picket fence.  We...

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I know about that shot.  A terrible tragedy.  How much do you have for carrying on your investigation?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: If you must know, virtually nothing.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: How many men are working with you on this?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: Less than you would guess.  Most days two to three assistant D.A.'s. A handful of police investigators.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: That's all you've had all this time?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: That's it.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I'm going to be very frank with you. You've done a great job, an astounding job considering the limited resources available to you.  But the best you can ever hope for is to stir up a lot of confusion.  You're not going to do this country any good, and you're not going to do yourself any good.  You don't belong here.  On this Mickey Mouse street with that cheap strip of bail bond shops.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: The job manages to keep me pretty busy.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Nonsense.  You should be in a job where you can make decisions that have impact, affect the world.  Here you're trying to climb up the steep side of Mount Everest.

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: I propose you accept an appointment to the bench in Federal District Court and move into a job worthy of your talent.  Do you have any idea, do you have any conception of how easily such an appointment can be arranged?

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: And what would I have to do?

turns.speaker: MILLER
turns.text: Stop your investigation... it was a magnificent effort but it's over and done with.  The press is already on your behind and that's only the beginning, my boy, only the beginning.

turns.speaker: JIM
turns.text: How long do you think it would take me to be appointed?

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: Hello.  Is this Jim Garrison's daughter?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: Virginia or Elizabeth?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Virginia.

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: Virginia, you're a lucky little girl. Your daddy has entered you in a beauty contest.  Would you like to be in a beauty contest?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: That sounds fun.

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: I need some information from you then.  How old are you?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Six.

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: And how tall are you?

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: And you get of from school at 3 every day?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: MALE VOICE
turns.text: Do you walk home?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Uh huh.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Then do you understand that I cannot tell the truth here?  In Dallas. That there are people here who do not want me to tell the truth... who do not want me to have a retrial?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Mr. Ruby, I really can't see why you can't tell us now.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: When are you going back to Washington, sir?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: I am going back very shortly after we finish this hearing - I am going to have some lunch.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Can I make a statement?  If you request me to go back to Washington with you right now, that is if you want to hear further testimony from me, can you do that?  Can you take me with you?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: No, that could not be done, Mr. Ruby. There are a good many things involved in that.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What are they?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Well, the public attention it would attract.  And we have no place for you there to be safe, we're not law enforcement officials, and many things are at stake in this affair, Mr. Ruby.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: But if I am eliminated there won't be any way of knowing.  Consequently a whole new form of government is going to take over this country, and I know I won't live to see you another time.  My life is in danger here. Do I sound screwy?

turns.speaker: OFFICIAL
turns.text: Well I don't know what can be done, Mr. Ruby, because I don't know what you anticipate we will encounter.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Then you don't stand a chance, Mr. Chief Justice, you have a lost cause. All I want is a lie detector test, and you refuse to give it to me. Because as it stands now - and the truth serum - how do you pronounce it - Pentothal - whatever it is. They will not give it to me, because I want to tell the truth... And then I want to leave this world.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Can I help you?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Yes, you have a suit I've had my eye on.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: This looks pretty good on me.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Are you kidding, it looks great. You wear this to a business meeting, you're the badass in the room. But you can go out dancing in this too. It's a total power suit.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I think I'm gonna just get this for today. I'm in kind of a hurry. Would you mind ringing this up while I change out of it?

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Not a problem.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I'm sorry, I just decided to stay in the suit -- get out of that damn uniform.

turns.speaker: AMY
turns.text: Oh, that's not a problem.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Tomorrow I'll talk to your probation officer. Karen's a good kid, but she's mad at you, because you lied to her. This business about your grandmother's funeral

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: I went. I did. I took my mother and little brother.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: But you didn't ask permission. You broke a trust. If you had asked, Karen probably would have let you. I'm sure she would.

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: I know. That's why I went.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: But then you told her you were home.

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: Sure, 'cause I didn't ask her if I could go.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I don't know. Maybe it's a language problem.  Anita, you ever cause this much heartache over something that could easily be avoided, I'll never write you again. You understand?

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I mean it. I don't care how many times your mother calls or how much she cries.

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: I understand.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Then say "Yes, Max. I understand."

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: Yes, Max, I understand.

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: So you're gonna call Karen tomorrow?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'll call her.

turns.speaker: ANITA
turns.text: Won't forget?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I won't forget.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: What the fuck can I say? I'm serious, man. What the fuck can I say? Thank you... thank you... thank you.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Who was there for your ass?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: You were there for me.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: You.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: You see, it works like this. You get your ass in trouble, I get your ass out. That's my job. And I don't mind tellin ya, nigga, it's steady work.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I'm still scared as a motherfucker, Ordell. They talkin' like they serious 'bout me doin' that machine gun time.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Naw, man. They just tryin' to put a fright in your ass.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: If that's what they want to do, they're doin' it.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: How old is that machine gun shit?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Three years.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Three years. That crime's old, man. They ain't got room in prison for all the motherfuckers out there killin' people. How they gonna find room for you?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: That's not what they're tellin' me.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: That's why they call it "fuckin' with ya." Now you wanna hear how we retaliate?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Hey, c'mon in, man. I was just -- you know -- smokin' a fatty, watchin' TV.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Naw, man. I gotta be someplace. I was kinda hopin you could come with me.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: What'd ya mean?

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Look, I hate to be the kinda nigga, does a nigga a favor -- then BAM -- hits a nigga up for a favor in return. But I'm afraid I gotta be that kinda nigga.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: I need a favor.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: That requires me goin' out tonight?

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: A bit.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Aaaaawww man, I wasn't plannin' on goin' no place. It's twelve o'clock, man. I'm home, I'm high --

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Why the fuck you at home? Cause I spent ten thousand dollars gittin' your ass home.  Look, I gotta problem. I need help, and you can help me.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: What's the problem?

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Well, it ain't so much a problem a a situation. Remember I sold those three M-60 machine guns outta the five I got?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: I'm gonna sell the other two tonight. This group of Koreans in Koreatown have started a Neighborhood Watch kinda thing. And they want a few weapons so the neighborhood niggas know they mean business. So I'm gonna sell 'em my two machine guns tonight. Only problem, I ain't never dealt with these Koreans before. Now I ain't worried. Asians are by and large real dependable. They don't want no trouble. You might argue about price, but you ain't gotta worry about them shootin' you in the back. But I got me kind of a rule. Never do business with nobody you ain't never done business with before without backup. That's why I need you, backup.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Man, I ain't ready to be goin' out nowhere --

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Let me finish. Can I finish?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Go ahead.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Fuck that shit, man. I ain't shootin' anybody.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: What the fuck I tell you. You don't hafta shoot nobody. Just hold the gun. They'll get the idea.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I ain't gittin' in that trunk.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: We're only goin' to Koreatown. You'll be in there -- ten minutes.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Uh-uh. I ain't riding in that trunk no minutes. Why don't I just ride with you?

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: You can't ride with me. The surprise effect is ninety percent of it.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Well, I'm sorry, man, but I ain't gittin' in that trunk.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: I can't believe you do me this way.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I ain't doin' you no way. I just ain't climbin' in that trunk. I got a problem with small places.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Well, my ass has got a problem spending ten thousand dollars of my own goddam money to get ungrateful, peanuthead niggas outta jail, but I do it --

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Look, man, I know I owe you --

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Well, if you owe me, git your ass in the trunk.

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: I wanna help you, but I don't wanna be locked in the trunk of no car.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: You think I wanted to spend ten thousand dollars on your ass?

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: Answer the question, nigga. Do you think I wanted to spend the thousand dollars on your ass? Yes or no?

turns.speaker: BEAUMONT
turns.text: Course you didn't.

turns.speaker: ORDELL
turns.text: But the only way to help you was to do that, so I did it.  Okay, how 'bout this? After we're through fuckin' with these Koreans, I take you to Roscoe's Chicken and Waffles. My treat.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Does he have the marked bills on him?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: In his inside coat pocket.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Why were you with him?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I went to give him his refund, so he wouldn't have to come here.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: How'd you know where he was?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I found out.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: And you didn't tell the Police?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I told Jackie, and Jackie said you wanted him.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: I'd say there's about, oh, fifty thousand dollars here. What would you say Ray?

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: That looks like fifty thousand dollars from here.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: You got a good lawyer?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Can she afford a good one is the question. Otherwise she'll be in Sybill Brand three weeks easy before the Public Defender gets around to her.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: Ever heard of a fella named Beaumont Livingston?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Great, you're here.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: Hey, Jackie.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: She wants to make a deal.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: She sound scared?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: She almost sounds scared.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: What's she want?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: She wants to go back to work.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: What's she willing to give us?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: She hasn't one into specifics yet, she's been waiting for you.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: She knows it's my case?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: She ain't said it, but she's not stupid, she knows it's you who wants her.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: We are. Don't worry about it.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: Every step of this goes in my report.  I am now taking a manila envelope from the subject's flight bag.

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: The envelope contains currency... all the same denomination, one-hundred- dollar bills. Now, I'm counting it.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: What time do you have to be there?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Can I have a word with you?

turns.speaker: NICOLET
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Hi, I'm Detective Mark Dargus. L.A.P.D. can I ask what you have in that bag?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: The usual things. I'm a flight attendant with Cabo Air.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I doubt it.  Who's your friend?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: This is Special Agent Ray Nicolet with Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms. Would you mind if we looked in that bag?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Would I mind? Do I have a choice?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: You have the right to say "no." And I have the right to make you wait here with Ray while I go get a warrant. And if I don't want to go through all that trouble, I could just take you in on suspicion.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Suspicion of what?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: This is your money?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: If I were to tell you "no it isn't..."

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: You should know if you bring in anything over ten thousand you have to declare it. You forgot or what? You could get a two hundred and fifty thousand dollar fine, plus two years in prison. Now you want to talk to us about it, or you want to talk to Customs?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I'm not saying another word.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Hey, this is my office. There's no smoking.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Arrest me.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I'm not a loser.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Oh, you're both? In 1985 you were flying for TWA and got busted for carrying drugs. You were carrying them for a pilot husband of yours. He did time and you got off. But that ended your career with the big airlines. Cut to thirteen years later. You're forty-four years of age. You're flying for the shittiest little shuttle-fucking piece of shit Mexican airline that there is. Where you make a whopping twelve-thousand dollars a year. That ain't a hulluva lot to show for a twenty year career. And to top it off, you're going to jail. Now true, the judge, even with your prior, will probably only give you a year or two. But this doesn't seem like the time of life you got years to throw away.  Now, we don't like trying losers like they're criminals. But in the absence of a criminal, we will try you. Now, wasn't this money given to you by an American living in Mexico by the name of Cedric Walker?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Help yourself.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: While you're at it, let me see what else is in there. You mind?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: My pocketbook.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: What's in it?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Beauty products.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: That's my diet shit.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Oh, I wouldn't be so sure. What with all the cash, I think I could go with Conspiracy to Traffic.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I'm tellin' you, I don't know nothin' about that fuckin' shit.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Let me have a word outside with Agent Nicolet for a moment?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Take your time.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Help us do what?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Help you get Ordell Robbie.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: But now you're telling us now you do.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: 'Course I do -- I deliver money for him.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: You don't want much, do you?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Can you do it or not?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: How was your flight?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Fine.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: Bet you're happy to be working again.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Four thirty. I'm meeting a woman.

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: What's her name?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: He wouldn't say. You gonna follow her?

turns.speaker: DARGUS
turns.text: She leaves, somebody'll be on her.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: But you're not going to stop her?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I can give you a lift home if you'd like?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Are you really a bail bondsman?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Who do you think I am?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I gave you my card there.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Can I see your I.D.?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You're serious?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Who put up my bond? Ordell?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: In cash.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Can we stop for cigarettes?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Sure, ever been to the Riverbottom?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: It's okay. It's a cop hangout.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Couldn't we just stop at a seven- eleven?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I thought you might want a drink?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I'd love one, but not there.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: We could stop at the Hilton by the airport.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Is it dark?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: It's kind of a sports bar

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: That doesn't sound dark.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Why does it need to be dark?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: 'Cause I look like I just got outta jail, that's why. You droppin' me off at home, right? There's a place by me.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: You gain weight?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Ten pounds. I lose it and put it back on.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: That's why I don't quit. If I can't fly anymore, I'm gonna have a bitch of a time gettin' my brand.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What's your brand?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Davidoffs. I get 'em in Mexico. They're hard to find here. I was locked up with the last two getting legal advice from a woman who was in for bustin' her boyfriend's head open with a baseball bat.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Was she helpful?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: She was more helpful than the fuckin' Public Defender.  I don't know -- I guess what I need is a lawyer, find out what my options are.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You know, I figured out the other day I've written something like fifteen thousand bonds since I've been in the business. I'd say about eighty percent of them were at least drug related. If you want, I can help you look at your options.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: You're not tired of it?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I am, as a matter of fact.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What have they told you?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: So far I've been told I can cooperate and get probation, maybe. Or, I can stand mute and get as much as five years. Does that sound right?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'd say if you're tried and found guilty you won't get more than a year and a day. That's State time. Prison.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Shit.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: But they won't want to take you to trial. They'll offer you simple Possession, a few months of County time, and a year or two probation.  How 'bout another?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You know who put the dope in your bag?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Yeah, but that's not what this was about. They were fuckin waitin' for my ass. They knew I had that money, they even knew the amount. The one who searched my bag, from L.A.P.D., Dargus, hardly even looked at it. "Oh, I'd say there's fifty thousand here. What would you say?" But all they could do was threaten me and hand me over to Customs, and I could tell they didn't want to do that.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: They wanted you to tell them what you know.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I had 'em too. I burnt those two Starky and Hutch motherfuckers down. Then their asses lucked out and found that coke.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What did they want to know?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Who gave me the money and who I was giving it to. And some guy they found in a trunk with his head blown off. Said it was him who told them 'bout me.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: That would be Beaumont Livingston.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: That's him. How do you know 'em?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I wrote him on Monday. They found him dead on Tuesday.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Ordell pick up his bond?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Same as you. Ten thousand.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: The federal agent kinda half hinted Ordell might of done Beaumont.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You mentioned a guy from L.A.P.D., but you didn't mention the Federal.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I didn't?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: No, you didn't. What branch?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Ray Nicolet with Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: He's the one who wants you.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: It was the other guy who busted me.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: 'Cause if he busted you, you'd play hell bonding out of federal court. He doesn't want you mad at him, he wants you to tell him what you know. He uses you to get a line on Ordell, make a case, then take him federal. You know what Ordell's into?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I have a pretty good idea. Ordell ain't no bootlegger and I doubt he's smugglin' Cuban cigars. So that only leaves one thing an A.T.F. man would be interested in.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I used to bring over ten thousand at a time. That's the legal limit, so I never brought more than that.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: How many trips did you make?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: With ten thousand? Nine.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: He's got that kinda money?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: It's all in lock boxes in a Mexico bank. But he's got a problem. He's -- what do you call it when you got money, but don't have cash?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Cash poor?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: That's it. He's cash poor. He kept on me till I finally said okay. I'll bring whatever fits in a nine-by- twelve envelope. I got paid five hundred dollars, and his friend, Mr. Walker, in Mexico gave me the envelope.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: If you knew bringing anything over ten thousand was against the law, why not pack a hundred grand?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Whatever it was had to fit in my bag and not hit you in the face if the bag was opened. This ain't solvin' my problem. I gotta figure out a way to either keep my job or get out of trouble. I'm off today, but if I can't leave the country I'm out of a job. And if I don't got a job, I can't hire a lawyer.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Ask A.T.F. They might give you permission.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: Yeah, if I cooperate.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Well, Jackie, you got caught, you're gonna have to give 'em something.

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: But if all I can give 'em is Ordell's name -- I don't really know shit about what he does or how he does it -- That don't give me much to bargain with.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Give 'em what you got. Offer to help. Show a willingness to be helpful. You want to stay out of jail, don't you?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: What'dya think?

turns.speaker: JACKIE
turns.text: I think maybe I have more options than I thought.
